text:
Hi. Right now we are about to board 
 a ferry to take us over to
Fraser Island world heritage site, the largest sand island in the world
It's going to be awesome.
Hi guys. So right now we are going on a four weel driving tour
of Fraser Island. Now 4 weel vehicle, like the one behind me,
are the only way to get around on the island, because all the
roads are made of sand. Like that.
The coloured sands are absolutely intense in colour.
These loose bare sands are absolutely intense in colour.

A lot of erotion, being exposed to elements, caused by 
 leaching of oxides that cause the bands of colour.
We have bright pinks, whites, yellows, you name it. Absolutely amazing.
Welcome to Lake McKenzie. Wow, take a look.
So Lake McKenzie is one of 40 perched dune lakes that are on
Fraser Island. Now a perched dune lake is a lake that is basically
sitting on top of a dune of sand, so all this, underneath all this
water is sand.
That colour blue is McKenzie, so we double back to the top,
then we come around to the station here,so after the rainforest

walk we are going to make our way 
 all the way down to the bottom.

Obviously there is a lot more to see 
 and do but...Its 128km from
here to there.
We are going on a nature walk though Fraser Island to see
some of the rainforest here. There is actually  suprising amount
of vegetation here, considering it is an island of sand.
Oh my gosh, this has got to be the biggest spider I have ever
seen in my life. What if it jumps? Girl: Turantulas don't jump.
That is not a tarantula. Is it? No it's not. It's fuzzy.

This is the biggest spider I have ever 
 seen in my life. And it's
in our washroom.
You managed to catch that. I'm very impressed.
Well is it poison? I don't know.
You should do that. Yea, it's a good idea.
Look at this. It's huge.
Alright, put him away. Far away.
